repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Because cython doesn't support ['e' format string](https://docs.python.org/3/library/struct.html#format-characters) and lacks `np.float16_t` as well,  it becomes difficult to accelerate float16 conversion in https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/19212 . Hence the PR is opened to solve the problem: pass a `np.float16` array from python to cython. 

Note that we don't hope to support arithmetical operation for float16 in the PR.

I'm not familiar with cython, any suggestion / help will be appreciated.

comment_data.body: If one tried to do arithmetic with float16, would it simply interpret them as ints? It'd be better to prohibit it than allow this. Perhaps typedef this as an (empty) struct (named npy_half) instead.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -331,6 +333,8 @@ cdef extern from "numpy/arrayobject.h":
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint96
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint128
 
+    ctypedef npy_uint16   npy_half

comment_data.body:
Hi, @robertwb . Thank your for your quick reply :-)

In tensorflow, we create a numpy array in Python, and we hope to convert it to Tensor. It's faster to hand the numpy array in C++ than in python, like the example below for uint16:

```python
def AppendFloat16ArrayToTensorProto(tensor_proto, np.ndarray[np.uint16_t, ndim=1] nparray):
      cdef long i, n
      n = nparray.size
      for i in range(n):
          tensor_proto.half_val.append(nparray[i])
```

However, because cython doesn't allow that we declare a `np.ndarray[np.float16_t, ndim=1] nparray`, we cannot do the same thing for `np.float16`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -331,6 +333,8 @@ cdef extern from "numpy/arrayobject.h":
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint96
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint128
 
+    ctypedef npy_uint16   npy_half

comment_data.body: Yes, I agree that it's dangerous if someone try to do float16 operator (not supported in fact). I think we should hide it as you said, and don't allow people to do it. However I have no good idea, could you give me more details (typedef it as an empty struct instead) ? Thank you very much.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -331,6 +333,8 @@ cdef extern from "numpy/arrayobject.h":
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint96
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint128
 
+    ctypedef npy_uint16   npy_half

comment_data.body:
Instead of `ctypedef npy_uint16   npy_half`, try

```
ctypedef struct npy_half:
    pass
```

(I'm not positive this will work, but think it should). This way you should be able to get and set `npy_half`s as values, and handle arrays of them, but not do arithmetic with them. (It won't change the definition under the hood, just Cython's interpretation if it.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -331,6 +333,8 @@ cdef extern from "numpy/arrayobject.h":
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint96
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint128
 
+    ctypedef npy_uint16   npy_half

comment_data.body:
@robertwb Hi, I try to use structure to define the type as suggested. However the failure below is raised. 

```bash
~/W/g/cython ❯❯❯ CFLAGS=-O0 python runtests.py -vv --no-cleanup numpy_memoryview
Python 3.6.3 |Anaconda custom (64-bit)| (default, Oct  6 2017, 12:04:38)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)]

Running tests against Cython 0.28.2 21d627c0bf499c56fa3ca2265687c6326daf4be6
Backends: c,cpp

runTest (__main__.CythonRunTestCase)
compiling (c) and running numpy_memoryview ...
=== C/C++ compiler output: ===
In file included from numpy_memoryview.c:594:
In file included from /Users/facai/Library/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/numpy/core/include/numpy/arrayobject.h:4:
In file included from /Users/facai/Library/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/numpy/core/include/numpy/ndarrayobject.h:18:
In file included from /Users/facai/Library/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/numpy/core/include/numpy/ndarraytypes.h:1816:
/Users/facai/Library/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/numpy/core/include/numpy/npy_1_7_deprecated_api.h:15:2: warning: "Using deprecated NumPy API, disable it by "          "#defining NPY_NO_DEPRECATED_API NPY_1_7_API_VERSION" [-W#warnings]
#warning "Using deprecated NumPy API, disable it by " \
 ^
numpy_memoryview.c:3237:44: error: offsetof requires struct, union, or class type, '__pyx_t_5numpy_float16_t' (aka 'unsigned short') invalid
  {&__Pyx_TypeInfo_nn_npy_uint16, "value", offsetof(__pyx_t_5numpy_float16_t, value)},
                                           ^        ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/lib/clang/9.0.0/include/stddef.h:120:24: note: expanded from macro 'offsetof'
#define offsetof(t, d) __builtin_offsetof(t, d)
                       ^                  ~
1 warning and 1 error generated.
```

I checked the c code generated by cython, 

```c
typedef npy_float16 __pyx_t_5numpy_float16_t;

static __Pyx_StructField __Pyx_StructFields_nn___pyx_t_5numpy_float16_t[] = {
  {&__Pyx_TypeInfo_nn_npy_uint16, "value", offsetof(__pyx_t_5numpy_float16_t, value)},
  {NULL, NULL, 0}
};
```

I think it's confused why `__pyx_t_5numpy_float16_t` is treated as `unsigned short`, rather than the structure we defined? Do you have any idea? Thanks very much.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -331,6 +333,10 @@ cdef extern from "numpy/arrayobject.h":
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint96
     ctypedef unsigned long long npy_uint128
 
+    ctypedef struct npy_half:
+        npy_uint16 value

repo.name: cython

title: Buffer checker supports the format string 'e' (for np.float16)
